Notes:

DO NOT confuse this original complete score with the official soundtrack released in 1994. The 1994 soundtrack release was completely re-recorded and some of the tracks were not even performed by Vangelis. 

HereÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s an excellent review from Bladezone.com ;


-------------------
Review by Sebastian.


This is it. Don't look any further. Had I known this release was on its wayÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ I would have found it difficult to give many of the other Blade Runner bootlegs the maximum rating in the past. 
This "Esper Productions" double cd private release isÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ to dateÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ the most comprehensive and accurate Blade Runner version to see the light of day. Where every other BR bootleg faltersÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ this version is resilient. I believe it's as close as we've ever come to the "Ultimate Blade Runner Soundtrack" so far. With so many Blade Runner boots out thereÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ many reading this review might be askingÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ "so what's the big deal?" I'll give it a shot:

BasicallyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ this release parts on a similar premise of the 2000 OWM release (i.e. a double disc release trying to take music from every BR source) but takes this idea much farther with never-before-heard
music and excellent production quality. For the first timeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ this release has virtually ALL of the music from the film (Directors Cut and 1982 theatrical release). Highlights of new goodies on these
discs:

- Most noteworthyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ this release debuts "Thinking of Rachael" - the shorter and different take of the Love ThemeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ (heard only in the 1982 theatrical release where Deckard dozes off on his piano). A first on any release.

- For the first timeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ the incidental music heard when Deckard wakes RachaelÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ just before their escape at the end of the film is present on the track titled "Rachael Sleeps."

- At long lastÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ (as in the film itself) the eerie electronic rumblings leading into the "Love Theme" is expanded and presented in its complete formÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ titled "I am the Business." (The recent Deck Music and Deck Art releases decide to "chop up" this sequence into several parts for no apparent reason).

- Incidental music from the Esper photo examination film sequence is present on the track titled "Esper Analysis."

- The "Prologue and Main Titles" track contains the original "LAÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ November 2019" sound effect cue leading into the Main TitlesÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ as heard in the film itself. (The Deck Music and Deck Art releases
layered a spinner effect over it).

- The track titled "Deckard Enters the Bradbury" also has expanded musicÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ not heard on any BR release.

- For the first timeÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ the complete "Tears in Rain" dialog is presented here (i.e. "time to die" omitted from other versions).

- LastlyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ this release contains interesting new mixes and transitionsÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ (i.e. the fusion featured on the track titled "Sushi Bar-Damask Rose").

As gathered from reading many BR reviews in the pastÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ some fans might find the brief dialog sequences distractingÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ preferring the musical purity principle of the "Gongo" or "BR 2001" releases. NonethelessÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ it's clear that this Esper Productions release is extremely true to the film's atmospheric offerings while presenting all of the major themes in a very coherent and original manner. For thisÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ and it's many new additions I find this "Esper Edition" BR release as close to perfection as it gets. TrulyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…Â¡ a must have.

***** (5/5 stars)
